Build: I-20030715
I'm encountering the NPE pasted below from Workbench.restart() when any Update 
manager activities that require a restart are being executed.
For example, 
1. Help->Software Updates->Manage Configuration...
2. The root of the tree should be pre-selected.  Of the available tasks on the 
right, select 'Revert to Previous Configuration'.
3. Select a configuration from the list.  Press Finish.  Choose yes to restart.
You will get a series of null pointers.

i'm not familiar enough this install/update to get it to restart in the manner you described.

with the latest build 0716, i added an action to the help menu to invoke restart directly and did not have any problems - no log entry, etc. 

0716 lacks the method Workbench.updateContexts() in your stack trace below -  code in this area was changed yesterday to fix another M2 bug - i suspect the problems were related and took care of itself.

if you can reproduce this problem using the install/update path, please let me know right away.
thanks.

To reproduce the problem, go to Help>SofwareUpdates>Find and Install.. to 
launch the install wizard. Select the second option (install new features), 
click next. On the Sites page, all a remote site with the url 
http://update.eclipse.org/testUpdates. Click next to search the site. This 
will find a bunch of features. Select the SDK examples feature (either one) 
and install it. Answer yes to restart. 
After restart, go to Help>Software Updates>Manage Configuration, and disable 
the feature you just installed. Answer yes when prompted to restart.
The error message will popup.

It looks like the problem is caused by the first line in
Workbench.updateCommandsAndContexts():

IWorkbenchWindow activeWorkbenchWindow = ....

and next you do
.... (WorkbenchWindow)activeWorkbenchWindow

and get a ClassCastException because the window is of type
class org.eclipse.update.internal.ui.ConfigurationManagerWindow
which implements IWorkbenchWindow, but is not a WorkbenchWindow.

I know that the platform UI team will ask 'why do you implement that interface 
to begin with' :-).

We are creating our own window because we don't want to register views and 
perspectives. We have a Configuration Manager that opens into a separate  
window with two views (tree view and a preview, separated with a splitter). We 
don't want to share these views (they cannot appear in any perspective) and we 
don't want to have a perspective. For that reason, we create our own workbench 
window that is modal and host the two views ourselves. We are passing our 
implementations of view sites to ensure the correct life cycle behaviour.

This implementation is a result of many problems we had in 2.1 with Update 
Manager perspective. This way we send a clear message that Configuration 
Manager has nothing to do with the normal development, its views cannot be 
added to other perspectives and by being modal, it prevents you from doing 
anything else while it is open.

A question can be asked: why isn't configuration manager a dialog instead of a 
window? Because:

1) We need the tool bar for manager actions
2) We need the status line for long-lasting operations (progress bar)
3) The user experience is one of browsing the tree view, reading the tasks in 
the preview and executing them (some of them may open wizards). This usage 
mode would be out of place in a dialog.

thanks for the info, but i wasn't going to ask.. :)
(i've caused enough problems today that i probably shouldn't criticize anyone else..)

i've fixed up this case (i did assume the only implementation was Workbench)
i'll close it..
